en.title: Install webdesign.io
en.content:
Before starting, you need to make sure your system has Node.js version 6 (or upper) installed. If it is not the case, please [install Node.js using this link](https://nodejs.org).

### 1. Install webdesign.io CLI
-------
webdesign.io CLI let you develop websites right on your local machine.

With the CLI, you can initialize a new site and start workin on it using any text editor. And thanks to webdesign.io built-in web server, you can preview the site with your computer's web browser without even setting up a database.

The CLI can also deploy sites to any webdesign.io Engine using the `webdesignio deploy` command. Your changes will immediately be reflected on that site without restarting or making any changes to the Engine server app.

To help you work faster, webdesign.io comes with pre-defined workflows like Pug (former JADE) and it easy to integrate it in your current flow. It also works well with source version control systems like git and svn.

**Install webdesign.io**
```
npm install -g @webdesignio/cli
```

en.title: Create a new site
en.content:
### 2. Create a new site
-------
We start with creating a first website, using our webdesign.io-boilerplate.

**Initialize a new website**
```
webdesignio init <mywebsite>
```

For practical reasons, we will use webdesignio.com as our deployment target but you're absolutely free to use your own Engine on EC2, Digital Ocean, Engine Yard, Linodes, Heroku or your own server. Don't forget, everything is open source here.

If you don't have an account, it will create one for you.

> **NOTE**: Currently the CLI also creates an account for [surge.sh](https://surge.sh/) since this is our current way to upload to AWS S3.

**Launch the webdesign.io server**
```
npm start
```

Open your browser at this address [http://localhost:3000/](http://localhost:3000/), you should see the boilerplate.

en.title: Deploy and edit contents  online
en.content:
### 3. Deploy the site
------

Now we have a working site, we want to see it working online. That's the role of the webdesign.io engine.

**Now, let's deploy our site!**
```
webdesignio deploy
```
**That's it! The CLI will show two addresses**
```
    > Access the backend here: https://<< mywebsite>>.webdesignio.com
    > Your website will be published at the following urls:
    >     - language en: https://showcase-b1aho38ke-en.surge.sh
```

Visit the website: `https://showcase-b1aho38ke-en.surge.sh`.

Edit the website: `https://<< mywebsite>>.webdesignio.com`.

### 4. Modify the live content of your site!
--------

Go to your `<< mywebsite>>.webdesignio.com` domain and sign in with the credentials you entered in the CLI.

You will see the boilerplate page. You can now edit contents by just clicking into it. Press "Save" to save and publish the changes.

That's it!

en.title: What next?
en.content:
In less than 5 minutes, you were able to create a website, deploy it online and edit the contents in the frontend.

**We call that Penguin-Power :-)**

### 5. What next?
--------

As a next step, you will figure out how to use your own website or template.

It is really easy to become productive with webdesign.io. After 15 minutes, you will actually have your own website online and you will edit it.

What we will go through:
- Overview Structure (Where goes what?)
- Asset Function (How to link to static files like *.css and *.js)
- Components (How to make contents editable?)
- Save (How to save changes?)
- InnerHTML vs Contents

When you're done, just deploy your changes with the `webdesignio deploy` command!

en.title: Overview Structure
en.content:
### 6. Overview Structure
--------

Getting started with your own design!

The boilerplate comes with these folders:

- `data/`     - Contains contents (json files) if you have changed sth. in the frontend.
- `dist/`       - Containts folders for CMS-output. Don't change anything here.
- `src/`         - All your HTML files go here!  
- `static/`   - All static assets (Images, Css, Javascript, ...)

#### HTML Files

- `src/pages/` - Copy all your HTML files here.
- `src/objects/` - Copy all your HTML files for Objects (e.g. single Blog-Post, single Project) here. [Read more about Objects](link to the card.)

#### Static Files

- `static/` - Copy all your Static files here.

Use the asset-function (explained in the next step) to reference them.
